The 'University of Virginia' (often abbreviated as 'UVA', 'UVa', or 'Virginia')
is a public research university in Charlottesville, Virginia, United States. It
was conceived and designed by U.S. President Thomas Jefferson, and established
in 1819. UVA's initial Board of Visitors included former Presidents of the
United States Thomas Jefferson, James Madison, and James Monroe. Monroe owned
the initial site of the University, which was mostly farmland. His law office
and farmhouse are now the site of Brown College at Monroe Hill, a residential
college at UVA. HistArch
[http://www.histarch.uiuc.edu/highland/ashlawn2.html An Account of James
Monroe's Land Holdings] Retrieved 25 January 2012

UVA is one of the eight original Public Ivy universities, and it is the only
university campus in the United States that is designated a World Heritage Site
by UNESCO. designating Monticello and the Academical Village of Thomas
Jefferson. In the 2013 edition of U.S. News and World Report's National
University Rankings, the school was listed as America's 2nd best public
university; tied with UCLA and surpassed only by UC Berkeley. http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-
colleges/rankings/national-universities/top-public
